bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kotak iskwêw sipwêhtêw . Another woman set out.
sîpîhk itohtêw , kâ-wâpamât nâpêwah êh-pêcicimêyit . She came to a river, and there she saw a man approaching in a canoe.
pôsih , itik . “Get in,” he said to her.
pôsiw . She stepped aboard.
pôt ôhih êh-kitâpamât , âyîtaw kîh-ohkwâkaniyiwa . There, when she looked at him, he had a face at either side of his head.
êkwah mâtôw . Then she wept.

nika-pimâtisin , êh-itêyihtaman cî ? itik ;
ê-wîh-môwitân , itik . “Is it ‘Do let me live!’ you are thinking?” he asked her; “My intention is to eat you,” he told her.
êkwah mâtôw . She wept.

seg.gloss: “Sit still! It is no use; I mean to eat you.”

p.seg: takosinwak ministikohk . They reached an island.
êkwah kapâw . He disembarked.

nôhkô , itwêw êkwah awa wîhtikôw ,
pê-nâs ; “Grandmother,” cried that Windigo, “Come fetch her;

seg.gloss: prepare to boil this person I am bringing.”

p.seg: pê-nâtêw nôcokêsiw . A little old woman came and fetched her.
pêsiwêw wîkihk . She brought her over yonder to her lodge.
êkwah kitâpamêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . The young woman gazed at her.
namoya kipa-pakisâpamin , itwêw nôcokêsiw ; “You don't stop staring at me,” said the little old woman;
misawâc ê-wîh-pakâsimitân , itêw . “What mater, since I am bound to boil you?” she said to her.

seg.gloss: “And so it is my grandchild! I had almost been her undoing.
Kill me, my grandchild.
Then set the whole string of my entrails into water.
That is what the Windigo will eat first.
Also you will cut off my arm;
‘Chop wood, grandmother!’ you will say;
‘You are to split wood!’
Then I shall really split wood.
And as for you, you will be running away.
Run with all your might.”

p.seg: tâpwê êkwah tapasîw . Then she ran away.
êkwah ôhkomah nikohtêyiwah . Her grandmother chopped firewood.
kêtahtawê takosin wîhtikôw . Soon the Windigo arrived.
nôhkôhô , pê-kîwê ! niwîh-mîcison , itwêw . “Grandmother, come home! I want to eat!” he cried.
cêskwah ! ninikohtân , itwêw . “Wait a bit! I am gathering wood,” she said.

seg.gloss: “Be quick, now!”
“Do you eat meanwhile.

p.seg: wîpâc nika-kîwân , itwêw nôtokêsiw , ospiton piko êh-nikohtêmakaniyik . I shall be back soon,” said the old woman, while her arm all by itself cut wood.
mîcisôw êkwah wîhtokôw . The windigo began to eat.
môwêw ôhkomah êkwah . He ate his grandmother.
ihkêyihtam êkâ mi-mayaw êh-takohtêyit ôhkomah . He was impatient becuase his grandmother was not coming promptly. CHECK mi-mayaw
êkwah ntonikêw . Then he began to search.
êkwah êh-otihtahk , pôt ômah ôhkomah ospitoniyiw kâ-pahkihtiniyik . When he came thee, behold, there his grandmother's arm fell to the ground.

seg.gloss: “Whither can you flee, you who have bereft me by killing my grandmother!
She cooked for me.

p.seg: kiwîh-pimitisahotin , itêw . I will chase you,” he called to her.
êkwah nawaswêw wîhtikôw awa . Then that Windigo started in pursuit.
êkwah tapasîw oskinîkiskwêw . The young woman fled.
kêtahtawê kisiwâk pêtwêwitamiyiwah . Soon he came close with noise.
êkwah mâkwêyimôw . She was in great distress.
nka-nipahik êkwah , itêyihtam . “Now he will kill me,” she thought.
otihtêw ayîsiyiniwah êh-owaskâhikaniyit . She came to a man who had a house.
tawinah ! niwîh-nipahik wîhtikôw , itêw . “Open! A Windigo is trying to kill me,” she called to him.
namoya tâpwêhtâk . He paid no heed to her.
kîpah , nistêsê ! kitimâkihtawin ! niwih-nipahik wîhtikôw , itêw . “Quickly, big brother! Take pity on me! A Windigo is trying to kill me,” she called to him.
piyis yôhtênamiyiwah . At last he opened the door.
pîhtokêw êkwah . She went in.
âsay takopahtâyiwah . The other had already got there on the run.

seg.gloss: “Open the door for me!

p.seg: niwîkimâkan nipêh-nawaswâtâw , itwêw . I come in pursuit of my wife,” he cried.
namoya tâpwêhtamawâw . His words went unheeded.

seg.gloss: “Quick, open! I want to see my wife.”

p.seg:
êkwah iskwêw ,
kâ wiyah , kâ yôhtênah ! Then the woman, “Don't! Do not open!

seg.gloss: He is a Windigo, not my husband.”

p.seg:
êkwah nâpêw ,
yôhtênah ! niwîkimâkan nipê-nâtâw . And the man, “Open! I have come to fetch my wife.”
namoya ! itêw . “No!” she cried.
kitahtawê nâpêw yôhtênam . Then at one time the man opened the door.
âpihtaw iskoh êh-pîhtokêyit nâpêwah , kipiwêpinam ; nipahêw . When the other man had got half-way in, he flung it shut; he killed him.
êkwah iskwêw wayawîw . Then the woman went out.
mihtah mihcêt otinam . She took a great amount of firewood.
êkwah pônam . Then she made a fire.
nâpêwah êkotah isiwêpinêw ; mêstihkaswêw . She threw that man into it; she burned him up.

êkwah ostêsah ,
kâyâ kêkway ôtinah ! Then her big brother, “Do not take anything!”

oyâkanisah êmihkwânisak sîsîpaskihkosak paskwahamâcôwinisah êh-miywâsikih , ê-sîkwâhkasot awah wîhtikôw . bowls, spoons, kettles, forks, all kinds of good things which had fallen out when the Windigo was burned.
otinam oyâkanis ; sîhtihkôhkanâhtam . She picked up a bowl; she could not let go of it.
ati-kotawipayiyiw . It began to sink into the earth.
nistêsê , nistêsê ! itwêw . “Brother, brother!” she cried.
pê-wayawiyiwah ostêsah ; otinamiyiwa . Out came her brother; he took the thing.

seg.gloss: “Do not take anything more!”

p.seg: pâh-pâstahamiyiwah kahkiyaw . He smashed all the things.
êkosi êkwah pîhtokêw . Then she went inside.
êkwah osîhtâyiwa nâpêwah ayôwinisah . The man made some garments.
êkwah postayôwinisêw êôkonih nâpêw-âyôwinisah . Then she put on those man's clothes.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then she went away.
kêtahtawê êh-pimohtêt kâ-wâpahtahk sâpohtawân êkot êh-akosiyit ayîsiyiniwah . Presently, as she walked along, she saw a buffalo-lane and a man sitting up aloft on it.
pê-nîhtakosiyiwah êh-âkwâskâkot . He came down and headed her off.
mêtawêtân , itik . “Let us try our strength,” he said to her.

namoya , itêw ;
nikîwân , itêw . “No,” she answered him; “I am on my way home,” she said to him.
piyis sâkôcimik . But at last he talked her into it.

kiya nîkân , itêw ;
mêtawêy , itêw . “You first,” he said to her; “Show your power,” he said to her.
êkwah mêtawêwak . Then they contended.
skwêw awah sâkôcihâw . The woman was defeated.
kîwêhtahik nâpêwah ôhô ; sâpohtawânihk tohtahik . That man took her home with him; he took her to the buffalo-lane.
êkwah misakamik wâpamêw pisisik iskwêwah êh-kaskihcikwanêskikâsôwit . There she saw a great crowd of none but women whose knees had been broken. CHECK misakamik

êkwah kakwêcimêw ,
tânsi êh-tôtâkoyêk ! Then she asked them, “What has he been doing to you?”

seg.gloss: “This person climbs trees;
he comes leaping down;
he falls on our knees;
as he lands he always breaks our bones.”
“Now, he shall not treat me this way!”

p.seg: pê-pîhtokêw . She came inside.
nâpêw kîhcêkosîw . The man climbed up.
ap êkotah ! itêw iskwêwah . “Sit there!” he told the woman.
êkwah iskwêw aw âpiw . Then the woman sat there.
êkwah kwâskwêkocin awa . He leaped into the air.
pîwâpisk itisinam iskwêw awa . The woman held out an iron bar.
kisisimêw ; nipahêw . She impaled him and killed him.
êkos îsi êkwah pasikôw . Then she rose to her feet.
miywêyihtamwak ôki iskwêwak , osâm êh-kitimahihcik . Those women rejoiced, for they had been miserably dealt with.

seg.gloss: “Go, all of you, to whatever place you came from!”

p.seg: namoya kiskêyihtamwak tântê k-êsi-sipwêhtêcik . They did not know from where they had come.
piyis êkwah iskwêw âtiht sipwêhtahêw wîkiwâhk isi . At last that woman took some of them away with her towards her home.
êkwah takosinwak nêtê . They arrived at yonder place.
mitâtaht iskwêwah wîcêwêw . She had ten women with her.
êkwah miywêyihtamiyiwah ostêsah êh-takosihk . Her brothers were glad when she arrived.
mitâtasiyiwah ostêsah . Ten was the number of her brothers.
êkwah mînah mitâtaht kâ-pîsiwât . And likewise ten were they whom she brought.
miyopayiyiwah ostêsah . Now her brothers fared well.
êkwah êkotah ayâwak . They stayed there.
wîwiyiwah ostêsah . Her brothers now had wives.
kêtahtawê kâ-sipwêhtêt mînah kîhtwâm . After a time she set out again.
wâwâskêsiwah kwâsihik . A stag took her away with him. LB: From here on the story is obscure.
êkwah pakwâtamiyiwah êh-kwâsihikot , kotakah mînah pisiskiwah . He did not like it when in turn other animals took her away.
êkwah wiya miywêyihtam iskwêw . But the woman herself liked it.
onâpêmiw wâwâskêsiwah . The stag was her husband.
êkwah êh-wacistwanihkêyit êkotah nakatik . Then he made a nest for her and left her there.

êh-kitôwit êkwah wâwâskêsiwah , êh-ppâmpahtâyit , sîpâ pêmpahtâyici iskwêwah êh-pimi-kîhkâmikot . Then when the stag bellowed as he ran about, whenever he ran by below there, the woman taunted him as he went by.
ayis nama nântaw kiy-isi-kîhtêkosiyiwah ta-pakamahokot . For he had no way of climbing up there to beat her.
kêtahtawê kâ-pê-kitôwit kisiwâk êyakonih onâpêmah . Then at one time, hither came that husband of hers and bellowed.

ôt ômah misiwê oy-ocikisiyiwa êy-ispinatimiht , êkwah mitonih ê-wih-nipahâhkatosôwit . He was all covered with scars here on his body where he had been attacked, and he was lean to the point of starvation.

êkwah wîhtamâk :
kistêsak wîh-nipahâhkatosôwak , itik ; Then he told her: “Your brothers are starving to death.

seg.gloss: Now I shall go feed my body to them.

p.seg: kâwih itâp nk-âpisisinin , itik . Afterwards I shall come back go life,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Very well!”

p.seg: êkwah itohtêw ostêsah . Then she went to her brothers.

seg.gloss: “But they are not to crack my bones as they eat.
They are to wrap them in a fresh hide;
they are to put them away somewhere.
When four nights have passed, I shall come running back.”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah nipahêw . So then she slew him.
ostêsah ê-kîh-nêwo-tipiskâyik takosiniyiwah . When four nights had passed, her brothers arrived.
êkwah kîstawâw awîtê ! itêw ostêsah . “So it is you who have come!” she said to her brothers.
mâtôw iskwêw ; mihtâtêw onâpêmah . She wept; she grieved for her husband.
êkosi wiy êyôkô . So much of this.
